Quantum federated learning based on gradient descent

Kai Yu1    Xin Zhang2    Zi Ye1    Gong-De Guo1    Song Lin1 1College of Computer and Cyber Security, Fujian Normal University, Fuzhou 350117, China
2College of Mathematics and Statistics, Fujian Normal University, Fuzhou 350117, China
Abstract

Federated learning is a distributed learning framework in machine learning, and has been widely studied recently. Generally speaking, there are two main challenges, high computational cost and the security of the transmitted message, in the federated learning process. To address these challenges, we utilize some intriguing characteristics of quantum mechanics to propose a framework for quantum federated learning based on gradient descent. In the proposed framework, it consists of two components. One is a quantum gradient descent algorithm, which has been demonstrated that it can achieve exponential acceleration in dataset scale and quadratic speedup in data dimensionality over the classical counterpart. Namely, the client can fast-train gradients on a quantum platform. The other is a quantum secure multi-party computation protocol that aims to calculate federated gradients safely. The security analysis is shown that this quantum protocol can resist some common external and internal attacks. That is, the local gradient can be aggregated securely. Finally, to illustrated the effectiveness of the proposed framework, we apply it to train federated linear regression models and successfully implement some key computation steps on the Qiskit quantum computing framework.

††preprint: APS/123-QED

I Introduction

Machine learning (ML) is the core of artificial intelligence, which has succeeded in a wide variety of tasks. An essential feature of these successful ML models is that they are data-driven and involve large amounts of data. In 2016, Google proposed a federated learning (FL) framework brendan2016 that allows machine learning models to improve automatically through data from multiple parties. A typical federation learning process is started with a server initializing a global model, which is shared with several participants (clients) for iterative training. For concreteness, clients train locally with the received model and their part of the data; the server aggregates these training results to generate a new global model and shares this with all clients. Ultimately, clients can get a machine learning model trained on multiple data sources without sharing their data with others. Undoubtedly, the FL framework is helped to enhance the performance of models and privacy-preserving practices in machine learning. However, in the era of big data, the amount of data from a single user is also huge. In this case, traditional machine learning is prone to computational disasters. Moreover, the training results are needed to transmit in the federated learning process, which may provide a chance for the attacker to infer user privacy. That is the security of the transmitted messages should also be ensured.

Quantum information processing is an emerging field that explores the interaction between quantum mechanics and information technology. It sustains to show its charm, attracting the attention of scholars. In 1984, Bennett and Brassard proposed the famous BB84 protocol bennett1984 , which perfectly achieves a key distribution task between two remote parties. Subsequently, scholars utilized quantum information processing to ensure information security and proposed a series of quantum cryptography protocols. In contrast to the security of classical cryptography protocols that are based on the assumption of computational complexity, these protocols’ security relies on physical properties such as the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, which makes them unconditionally secure in theory. Quantum cryptography has developed as a significant application of quantum information processing, including quantum key distribution Gisin2002 ; scarani2009 ; schwonnek2021 , quantum secret sharing PhysRevA.59.1829 ; PhysRevA.59.162 ; PhysRevLett.83.648 , quantum secure direct communication kim2002 ; PhysRevA.68.042317 , and so on. Another exciting application of quantum information processing is quantum computing. It provided quantum speedup to certain classes of problems that are intractable on classical computers. For example, the factorization of large numbers via Shor algorithm Shor1999 can provide exponential speedup. Furthermore, quantum computing has also made some advances in machine learning, such as the Harrow-Hassidim-Lloyd algorithm HHL , quantum support vector machine rebentrost2014 , quantum regression schuld2016 ; yu2019 ; chen2022 , quantum neural network rebentrost2018 ; PhysRevA.100.012334 , and so on.

Recently, scholars tried to explore quantum federated learning (QFL) to address the efficiency and security issues. In 2021, Chen and Yoo focused on the computational efficiency of FL. They provided a framework to train hybrid quantum-classical classifiers in a federated manner, which could help in distributing computational loads to quantum computing chen2021QFL . Li et al. emphasized the security issue of federated learning and utilized blind quantum computing to design a quantum delegate computing that could be extended to multi-party distributed learning li2021QFL . Inspired by the above works, we combine quantum computing and quantum cryptography to propose a framework for quantum federated learning based on gradient descent (QFLGD) in this paper. This framework is made up of two parts. One is a quantum gradient descent (QGD) algorithm for private single-party gradient estimation, which can let clients gain the classical gradients in each iteration. The analysis of its time complexity shows that can be achieved exponential acceleration in dataset scale and quadratic speedup in data dimensionality over the classical counterpart. Another is a quantum secure multi-party computation (QSMC) protocol that could securely calculate federated gradients. The proposed framework is adapted to train supervised machine learning models. To illustrate it, we apply the QFLGD framework to train a federated linear regression (FLR) model. And a small-scale experiment of computing the gradient is carried out on the Qiskit quantum computing framework.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Sec. II, we introduce the classical gradient descent algorithm and federated machine learning. Then we present the framework for quantum federated learning based on gradient descent in Sec. III. In Sec. IV, the time complexity and the security of QFLGD are analyzed. In Sec. V, we show the application of the proposed framework to train the federated linear regression model and give simulation experiments of some computation. Finally, we present our conclusion in Sec. VI.

II Preliminaries

II.1 Gradient descent algorithm

Supervised learning is a fundamental part of machine learning. It needs training the labeled data samples to adjust the weight vector 𝐰=(ω0,ω1,⋯,ωD−1)𝐰subscript𝜔0subscript𝜔1⋯subscript𝜔𝐷1\mathbf{w}=\left(\omega_{0},\omega_{1},\cdots,\omega_{D-1}\right) and then gets an effective machine learning model. Such as perceptron, predictive models, and so on. A crucial method for obtaining optimal weight is the gradient descent algorithm, which has strong stability.

For instance, letting (𝐱0,y0),(𝐱1,y1),⋯,(𝐱M−1,yM−1)subscript𝐱0subscript𝑦0subscript𝐱1subscript𝑦1⋯subscript𝐱𝑀1subscript𝑦𝑀1\left({\mathbf{x}_{0},y_{0}}\right),\left({\mathbf{x}_{1},y_{1}}\right),\cdots,\left({\mathbf{x}_{M-1},y_{M-1}}\right) be M𝑀M samples, where 𝐱i∈ℝDsubscript𝐱𝑖superscriptℝ𝐷\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{D} and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is the corresponding label. To train this model, we can apply the gradient descent method to minimize the following cost function,

min𝐰⁡E=12​M​∑i=0M−1[f​(𝐱i⋅𝐰)−yi]2,subscript𝐰𝐸12𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑀1superscriptdelimited-[]𝑓⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰subscript𝑦𝑖2{\min\limits_{\mathbf{w}}E}=\frac{1}{2M}{\sum\limits_{i=0}^{M-1}\left[{f\left({\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}}\right)-y_{i}}\right]^{2}}, (1)

where f𝑓f is the activation function. Taking the gradient of E𝐸E with respect to 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, we obtain

𝒈j​(𝐰)=1M​∑i=0M−1F​(𝐱i⋅𝐰)​𝐱ij,j=0,1,⋯,D−1.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝒈𝑗𝐰1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑀1𝐹⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗𝑗01⋯𝐷1\bm{g}^{j}\left(\mathbf{w}\right)=\frac{1}{M}{\sum\limits_{i=0}^{M-1}{F\left({\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}}\right)}}\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j},\quad j=0,1,\cdots,D-1. (2)

In the n𝑛nth iteration, the parameters are updated as

𝐰j​(n+1)=𝐰j​(n)−α×𝒈j​(𝐰​(n)),superscript𝐰𝑗𝑛1superscript𝐰𝑗𝑛𝛼superscript𝒈𝑗𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}^{j}\left({n+1}\right)=\mathbf{w}^{j}(n)-\alpha\times\bm{g}^{j}\left({\mathbf{w}(n)}\right), (3)

for j=0,1,⋯,D−1𝑗01⋯𝐷1j=0,1,\cdots,D-1, where α∈(0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1] is a learning factor. To terminate the iteration at a suitable moment, one strategy is that set a threshold ε𝜀\varepsilon about gradient. If ∑j=0D−1[𝒈j​(𝐰​(n))]2≤εsuperscriptsubscript𝑗0𝐷1superscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝒈𝑗𝐰𝑛2𝜀{\sum\limits_{j=0}^{D-1}\left[{\bm{g}^{j}\left(\mathbf{w}(n)\right)}\right]^{2}}\leq\varepsilon, the training is finished and then 𝐰​(n)𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}(n) is outputted.

II.2 Federated learning based on gradient descent

To further improve the performance of the ML models, it is needed to combine multi-party data for training. One of the widely used frameworks is federated learning based on gradient descent. In this case, each client trains the gradient of its data locally and then sends the results to server. The server updates the model parameters according to the user gradients and shares them with all clients. The framework of federated learning based on gradient descent algorithm is illustrated in Fig. 1.

Considering K𝐾K clients participated in the model training. The client BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k} (k=1,2,⋯,K𝑘12⋯𝐾k=1,2,\cdots,K) has Mksubscript𝑀𝑘M_{k} samples (𝐱0,y0),(𝐱1,y1),⋯,(𝐱Mk−1,yMk−1)subscript𝐱0subscript𝑦0subscript𝐱1subscript𝑦1⋯subscript𝐱subscript𝑀𝑘1subscript𝑦subscript𝑀𝑘1\left({\mathbf{x}_{0},y_{0}}\right),\left({\mathbf{x}_{1},y_{1}}\right),\cdots,\left({\mathbf{x}_{M_{k}-1},y_{M_{k}-1}}\right), where 𝐱i∈ℝDsubscript𝐱𝑖superscriptℝ𝐷\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{D}. And he utilizes the gradient descent algorithm to calculate the gradient of the local data as

𝒈kj​(𝐰)=1Mk​∑i=0Mk−1F​(𝐱i⋅𝐰)​𝐱ij,j=0,1,⋯,D−1,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑗𝐰1subscript𝑀𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖0subscript𝑀𝑘1𝐹⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗𝑗01⋯𝐷1\bm{g}_{k}^{j}\left(\mathbf{w}\right)=\frac{1}{M_{k}}{\sum\limits_{i=0}^{{M_{k}}-1}{F\left({\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}}\right)}}\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j},\quad j=0,1,\cdots,D-1, (4)

where 𝒈kj​(𝐰)subscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑗𝑘𝐰\bm{g}^{j}_{k}\left(\mathbf{w}\right) denotes the j𝑗jth element of the local gradient 𝒈k​(𝐰)subscript𝒈𝑘𝐰\bm{g}_{k}\left(\mathbf{w}\right).

Server Alice collects the gradients trained by all clients, and calculates the federated gradient

𝑮j​(𝐰)=∑k=1Kβk​𝒈kj​(𝐰),superscript𝑮𝑗𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑗𝐰\bm{G}^{j}\left(\mathbf{w}\right)={\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{\beta_{k}}{\bm{g}_{k}^{j}\left(\mathbf{w}\right)}}, (5)

where βk=Mk/(∑k=1KMk)subscript𝛽𝑘subscript𝑀𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑀𝑘{\beta_{k}}={M_{k}}/({\sum_{k=1}^{K}{M_{k}}}) and 𝑮j​(𝐰)superscript𝑮𝑗𝐰\bm{G}^{j}\left(\mathbf{w}\right) is represented as the j𝑗jth element of the federated gradient 𝑮​(𝐰)𝑮𝐰\bm{G}\left(\mathbf{w}\right). Then, Alice updates the model parameters

𝐰j​(n+1)=𝐰j​(n)−α×𝑮j​(𝐰​(n)),superscript𝐰𝑗𝑛1superscript𝐰𝑗𝑛𝛼superscript𝑮𝑗𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}^{j}\left({n+1}\right)=\mathbf{w}^{j}(n)-\alpha\times\bm{G}^{j}\left({\mathbf{w}(n)}\right), (6)

for j=0,1,⋯,D−1𝑗01⋯𝐷1j=0,1,\cdots,D-1, and distributes them to all clients. A signal is sent to clients to terminate training when ∑j=0D−1[𝑮j​(𝐰​(n))]2≤εsuperscriptsubscript𝑗0𝐷1superscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝑮𝑗𝐰𝑛2𝜀{\sum\limits_{j=0}^{D-1}\left[{\bm{G}^{j}\left(\mathbf{w}(n)\right)}\right]^{2}}\leq\varepsilon. The entire process of the federated learning based on gradient descent (FLGD) is shown in Fig. 2.

For the client BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k}, the main difficulty to implement the training is the evaluation of the summation (as shown in Eq. (4)) for j=0,1,⋯,D−1𝑗01⋯𝐷1j=0,1,\cdots,D-1. It costs O​(D)𝑂𝐷O(D) to estimate the inner product 𝐱i⋅𝐰⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰{\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}} and contains M𝑀M summations. This process need to be repeated D𝐷D attempts to estimate the all elements of 𝒈k​(𝐰)subscript𝒈𝑘𝐰\bm{g}_{k}\left(\mathbf{w}\right). Totally, the complexity of estimating the local gradient 𝒈k​(𝐰)subscript𝒈𝑘𝐰\bm{g}_{k}\left(\mathbf{w}\right) on a classical computer is O​(M​D2)𝑂𝑀superscript𝐷2O(MD^{2}). In the era of big data, this is certainly very computationally expensive. Furthermore, a secure and efficient computation of the federal gradient to prevent unscrupulous individuals from obtaining any data information is also valuable.

III Quantum Federated Learning based on Gradient Descent Algorithm

III.1 The whole model of QFLGD

In this section, we briefly introduce the model of quantum federated learning based on gradient descent. In this framework, a quantum gradient descent (QGD) algorithm (shown in Sec. III.2) is first presented. Each client BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k} utilizes this algorithm to accelerate training on their data gradients. Then, a quantum secure multi-party computation (QSMC) protocol is designed (shown in Sec. III.3). The server and clients use this protocol to communicate and securely calculate the federated gradient. Finally, Alice updates the federated model parameters according to Eq. (6) and broadcasts them to BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k} (k=1,2,⋯,K𝑘12⋯𝐾k=1,2,\cdots,K). The schematic illustration of the QFLGD model is exhibited in Fig. 3.

III.2 Quantum gradient descent algorithm

In this section, a quantum algorithm to approximate the gradients is proposed. Considering a dataset 𝐗=[𝐱0,𝐱1,⋯,𝐱M−1]𝐗subscript𝐱0subscript𝐱1⋯subscript𝐱𝑀1\mathbf{X}=\left[\mathbf{x}_{0},\mathbf{x}_{1},\cdots,\mathbf{x}_{M-1}\right], where 𝐱i∈ℝDsubscript𝐱𝑖superscriptℝ𝐷\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{D}. And 𝐲=(y0,y1,⋯,yM−1)𝐲subscript𝑦0subscript𝑦1⋯subscript𝑦𝑀1\mathbf{y}=\left(y_{0},y_{1},\cdots,y_{M-1}\right) is the corresponding label of each sample of 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}, respectively. For convenience, assuming that D=2L𝐷superscript2𝐿D=2^{L} for some L𝐿L; otherwise, some zeros are inserted into the vector. And the quantum oracles

and

are provided, where 𝐱ijsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j} represents the j𝑗jth element of the i𝑖ith vector of the data set 𝐗𝐗\mathbf{X}. These two oracles can respectively access the entries of 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i}, 𝐲𝐲\mathbf{y} in time O​(polylog​(M​D))𝑂polylog𝑀𝐷O(\text{polylog}(MD)) and O​(polylog​(D))𝑂polylog𝐷O(\text{polylog}(D)) yu2019 ; wossnig2018 , when the data are stored in quantum random access memory (QRAM) giovannetti2008 with an appropriate data structure kerenidis2016 . In addition, the operation

is required, which could access the 222-norm of the vector 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i}. Inspired by mitarai2019 , Un​fsubscript𝑈𝑛𝑓U_{nf} can be implemented in time O​(polylog​(D)/ϵm)𝑂polylog𝐷subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚O\left({{\text{polylog}(D)}/\epsilon_{m}}\right) employing controlled rotation cong2016 and quantum phase estimation (QPE) brassard2002 . The details are shown in Appendix A.

According to the above assumptions, the processes of the QGD algorithm are described as follows.

(1) Extract data and parameter to the quantum state.

(1.1) In this step, the data information is extracted to a state |ϕ​(𝐱i)⟩ketitalic-ϕsubscript𝐱𝑖\left|{\phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)}\right\rangle. The details are presented in the following.

|ϕ​(𝐱i)⟩=1D​∑j=0D−1|j⟩2​[1−(c1​𝐱ij)2​|0⟩+c1​𝐱ij​|1⟩]4.ketitalic-ϕsubscript𝐱𝑖1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝐷1subscriptket𝑗2subscriptdelimited-[]1superscriptsubscript𝑐1superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗2ket0subscript𝑐1superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗ket14\left|{\phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)}\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{D}}{\sum\limits_{j=0}^{D-1}|j\rangle_{2}\left[\sqrt{1-({c_{1}\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j}})^{2}}|0\rangle+c_{1}\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j}|1\rangle\right]_{4}}. could be obtained via discarding the third register. Simplistically, this process is denoted as U𝐱isubscript𝑈subscript𝐱𝑖U_{\mathbf{x}_{i}}, which generates the state |ϕ​(𝐱i)⟩ketitalic-ϕsubscript𝐱𝑖\left|{\phi\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)}\right\rangle in time O​(polylog​(D)+q)𝑂polylog𝐷𝑞O(\text{polylog}(D)+q).

(1.2) In order to train the gradient, the parameter 𝐰​(n)𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}(n) should be introduced in the (n+1)𝑛1(n+1)th iteration. Thus, it is necessary to generate a quantum state, which contains the information of 𝐰​(n)𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}(n). Depending on the fact that the parameter is different in each iteration, there are two methods to prepare the quantum state.

One way is based on the assumption that QRAM is allowed to read and write frequently. For the information of 𝐰j​(n)superscript𝐰𝑗𝑛\mathbf{w}^{j}(n) (j=0,1,⋯,D−1𝑗01⋯𝐷1j=0,1,\cdots,D-1) are written in QRAM timely, the quantum state

This way can be implemented in time O​(polylog​(D)+q)𝑂polylog𝐷𝑞O(\text{polylog}(D)+q).

For another, the parameter is extracted to the quantum state based on the operation R​(ϑ)=cos⁡(ϑ)​|0⟩​⟨0|−sin⁡(ϑ)|0⟩​⟨1|+sin⁡(ϑ)|1⟩​⟨0|+cos⁡(ϑ)|1⟩​⟨1|𝑅italic-ϑitalic-ϑket0quantum-operator-product0italic-ϑ0quantum-operator-product1italic-ϑ1quantum-operator-product0italic-ϑ1bra1R(\vartheta)=\cos{(\vartheta)}|0\rangle\langle 0|-\sin{(\vartheta)}|0\rangle\langle 1|+\sin{(\vartheta)}|1\rangle\langle 0|+\cos{(\vartheta)}|1\rangle\langle 1|, which is inspired by Ref. shao2019fast . III.3 Quantum secure multi-party computation protocol

We will design a protocol to safely compute the federated gradients 𝑮​(𝐰)=∑k=1Kβk​𝒈k​(𝐰)𝑮𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛽𝑘subscript𝒈𝑘𝐰\bm{G}\left(\mathbf{w}\right)={\sum_{k=1}^{K}{\beta_{k}}{\bm{g}_{k}\left(\mathbf{w}\right)}} in this section. That is, calculating 𝑮​(𝐰)𝑮𝐰\bm{G}\left(\mathbf{w}\right) without revealing the local gradient 𝒈k​(𝐰)subscript𝒈𝑘𝐰{\bm{g}_{k}\left(\mathbf{w}\right)}. To do it, the server Alice is assumed to be a semi-honest who may misbehave on her own but cannot conspire with others. Moreover, the federated gradients are needed to be accurate to γ−1superscript𝛾1{\gamma}^{-1}. This means that γ​βk​𝒈kj​(𝐰)≥0𝛾subscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑗𝐰0\gamma{\beta_{k}}{\bm{g}_{k}^{j}(\mathbf{w})}\geq 0. Simply, the γ​βk​𝒈kj​(𝐰)𝛾subscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑗𝐰\gamma{\beta_{k}}{\bm{g}_{k}^{j}(\mathbf{w})} is marked as μkjsuperscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘𝑗\mu_{k}^{j}. And supposing that ∑k=1Kμkj<Ssuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘𝑗𝑆{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mu_{k}^{j}}<S. The further details are described as follows.

Step M1: Preparation. Alice announces γ𝛾{\gamma} and the global dataset scale (∑k=1KMk)superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑀𝑘(\sum_{k=1}^{K}{M_{k}}). At same time, the participants (server and clients) choose m𝑚m numbers disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} (i=1,2,⋯,m𝑖12⋯𝑚i=1,2,\cdots,m) which are mutually prime and satisfy d1×d2×⋯×dm=Ssubscript𝑑1subscript𝑑2⋯subscript𝑑𝑚𝑆d_{1}\times d_{2}\times\cdots\times d_{m}=S. Subsequently, BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k} (k=1,2,⋯,K)𝑘12⋯𝐾(k=1,2,\cdots,K) calculates his secret

sk,ij=μkj​mod​di.superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘𝑗modsubscript𝑑𝑖s_{k,i}^{j}=\mu_{k}^{j}~{}\text{mod}~{}d_{i}. (37)

Alice produces a disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i}-level (K+1)𝐾1(K+1)-particle GHZ state

|Ψ⟩=1di​∑q=0di−1|q⟩⨂(K+1),ketΨ1subscript𝑑𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑞0subscript𝑑𝑖1superscriptket𝑞tensor-product𝐾1\left|\Psi\right\rangle=\frac{1}{\sqrt{d_{i}}}{\sum\limits_{q=0}^{d_{i}-1}|q\rangle^{\bigotimes(K+1)}}, (38)

and marks the (K+1)𝐾1(K+1) particles by Q0,Q1,⋯,QKsubscript𝑄0subscript𝑄1⋯subscript𝑄𝐾Q_{0},Q_{1},\cdots,Q_{K}.

Step M2: Distribution. For the sake of checking the presence of eavesdroppers, Alice prepares K𝐾K sets of δ𝛿\delta decoy states, where each decoy photon randomly is in one of the states from the set V1={|p⟩}p=0di−1subscript𝑉1superscriptsubscriptket𝑝𝑝0subscript𝑑𝑖1V_{1}=\left\{\left|p\right\rangle\right\}_{p=0}^{d_{i}-1} and V2={F​|p⟩}p=0di−1subscript𝑉2superscriptsubscript𝐹ket𝑝𝑝0subscript𝑑𝑖1V_{2}=\left\{F\left|p\right\rangle\right\}_{p=0}^{d_{i}-1}. These sets are denoted as E1,E2,⋯,EKsubscript𝐸1subscript𝐸2⋯subscript𝐸𝐾E_{1},E_{2},\cdots,E_{K}, respectively. Then Alice inserts Qksubscript𝑄𝑘Q_{k} into Eksubscript𝐸𝑘E_{k} at a random position, and sends them to BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k} for k=1,2,⋯,K𝑘12⋯𝐾k=1,2,\cdots,K.

Step M3: Security checking. After receiving δ+1𝛿1\delta+1 particles, BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k} sends acknowledgements to Alice. Subsequently, the positions and the bases of the decoy photons are announced to BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k} by Alice. BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k} measures the decoy photons and returns the measurement results to Alice who then calculates the error rate by comparing the measurement results with initial states. If the error rate is higher than the threshold determined by the channel noise, Alice cancels this protocol and restarts it. Otherwise, the protocol is continued.

Step M4: Measurement and encoding. BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k} extracts all the decoy photons and discards them. Then, server and clients perform a measurement {F​|p⟩}p=0di−1superscriptsubscript𝐹ket𝑝𝑝0subscript𝑑𝑖1\left\{F\left|p\right\rangle\right\}_{p=0}^{d_{i}-1} on the remaining particles, respectively. The measurement results record as os,i,o1,i,⋯,oK,isubscript𝑜𝑠𝑖subscript𝑜1𝑖⋯subscript𝑜𝐾𝑖o_{s,i},o_{1,i},\cdots,o_{K,i} and these satisfy os,i+o1,i+⋯+oK,i=0​mod​disubscript𝑜𝑠𝑖subscript𝑜1𝑖⋯subscript𝑜𝐾𝑖0modsubscript𝑑𝑖o_{s,i}+o_{1,i}+\cdots+o_{K,i}=0~{}\text{mod}~{}d_{i}. Subsequently, BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k} encodes his data sk,i′⁣j=sk,ij+ok,isuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖′𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖𝑗subscript𝑜𝑘𝑖s_{k,i}^{\prime j}=s_{k,i}^{j}+o_{k,i} and sends it to Alice.

Step M5: Server’s computation. At this stage, Alice accumulates all the results sk,i′⁣jsuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖′𝑗s_{k,i}^{\prime j} to compute

(os+o1,i+s1,ij+o2,i+s2,ij​⋯+oK,i+sK,ij)​mod​di=(μ1j+μ2j+⋯+μKj)​mod​di.subscript𝑜𝑠subscript𝑜1𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑠1𝑖𝑗subscript𝑜2𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑠2𝑖𝑗⋯subscript𝑜𝐾𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑠𝐾𝑖𝑗modsubscript𝑑𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜇1𝑗superscriptsubscript𝜇2𝑗⋯superscriptsubscript𝜇𝐾𝑗modsubscript𝑑𝑖\begin{split}&\left({o_{s}+o_{1,i}+s_{1,i}^{j}+o_{2,i}+s_{2,i}^{j}\cdots+o_{K,i}+s_{K,i}^{j}}\right)~{}\text{mod}~{}d_{i}\\ =&\left({\mu_{1}^{j}}+{\mu_{2}^{j}}+\cdots+{\mu_{K}^{j}}\right)~{}\text{mod}~{}d_{i}.\end{split} (39)

For i=1,2,⋯,m𝑖12⋯𝑚i=1,2,\cdots,m, Alice can obtain m𝑚m equations such as Eq. (39). According to the Chinese remainder theorem, Alice compute the summation

(∑k=1Kμkj)​mod​S=∑k=1Kμkj.superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘𝑗mod𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘𝑗\left({\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{\mu_{k}^{j}}}\right)~{}\text{mod}~{}S=~{}{\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{\mu_{k}^{j}}}. (40)

And it is easy to get the federated gradient

𝑮j​(𝐰)=1γ​∑k=1Kμkj=∑k=1Kβk​𝒈kj​(𝐰).superscript𝑮𝑗𝐰1𝛾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑘𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑗𝐰\bm{G}^{j}\left(\mathbf{w}\right)=\frac{1}{\gamma}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{\mu_{k}^{j}}={\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{\beta_{k}}{\bm{g}_{k}^{j}(\mathbf{w})}}. (41)

After the similar processes, the federated gradient (𝑮0​(𝐰),𝑮1​(𝐰),⋯,𝑮D−1​(𝐰))superscript𝑮0𝐰superscript𝑮1𝐰⋯superscript𝑮𝐷1𝐰(\bm{G}^{0}(\mathbf{w}),\bm{G}^{1}(\mathbf{w}),\cdots,\bm{G}^{D-1}(\mathbf{w})) could be obtained by Alice. And she updates the parameters 𝐰​(n+1)=𝐰​(n)−α×𝑮​(𝐰​(n))𝐰𝑛1𝐰𝑛𝛼𝑮𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}({n+1})=\mathbf{w}(n)-\alpha\times\bm{G}\left({\mathbf{w}(n)}\right) and announces the parameters 𝐰​(n+1)𝐰𝑛1\mathbf{w}({n+1}). Moreover, the corresponding quantum state |𝐰​(n+1)⟩ket𝐰𝑛1|\mathbf{w}(n+1)\rangle can be prepared by the methods (as shown in step (1.2) of Sec. III.2), to perform a new round of the QFLGD framework. The above processes are repeated until the accuracy satisfies ∑j=0D−1[𝑮j​(𝐰)]2≤εsuperscriptsubscript𝑗0𝐷1superscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝑮𝑗𝐰2𝜀{\sum_{j=0}^{D-1}\left[{\bm{G}^{j}(\mathbf{w})}\right]^{2}}\leq\varepsilon.

In order to exhibit the protocol more clearly, a concrete example is proposed. could be obtained through a similar procedure. According to the Chinese remainder theorem, the federated gradient (3.5,6.06) is easy to get.

IV Analysis

In this section, we provide a brief analysis of the proposed framework. As discussed previously, the QGD algorithm (shown in Sec. III.2) enables clients to accelerate the training gradients on a local quantum computer. The QSMC protocol (shown in Sec. III.3) gives a method to securely update the federated parameters to protect the privacy of clients’ data. Therefore, two main aspects are considered in the analysis. One is the time complexity of QGD algorithm. The other is the security of QSMC protocol.

IV.1 Time complexity of the QGD algorithm

In the QFLGD framework, assuming that M1≤M2≤⋯≤MK≤Msubscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2⋯subscript𝑀𝐾𝑀M_{1}\leq M_{2}\leq\cdots\leq M_{K}\leq M. Namely, the dataset scale is at most M𝑀M. And all clients need to accomplish the gradient training before calculating the federated gradient. Thus the waiting time for the distributed training gradient is the time consumed to train the dataset which scale is M𝑀M. In the following, the time complexity of the QGD algorithm is analyzed with the M𝑀M-scale dataset.

In step (1)1(1), the time consumption is caused by the processes of U𝐱isubscript𝑈subscript𝐱𝑖U_{\mathbf{x}_{i}} and U𝐰subscript𝑈𝐰U_{\mathbf{w}}, which generate the states |ϕ​(𝐱i)⟩ketitalic-ϕsubscript𝐱𝑖\left|{\phi(\mathbf{x}_{i})}\right\rangle and |ϕ​(𝐰​(n))⟩ketitalic-ϕ𝐰𝑛\left|{\phi(\mathbf{w}(n))}\right\rangle about data information. It could be implemented in time O​(polylog​(M​D)+D+q)𝑂polylog𝑀𝐷𝐷𝑞O(\text{polylog}(MD)+D+q) with the help of the OXsubscript𝑂𝑋O_{X}, U​(ϑt)𝑈subscriptbold-italic-ϑ𝑡U(\bm{\vartheta}_{t}) and the controlled rotation operation HHL ; wossnig2018 . The q𝑞q is represented as the number of qubits which store the data information. Afterwards, U𝐱isubscript𝑈subscript𝐱𝑖U_{\mathbf{x}_{i}} and U𝐰subscript𝑈𝐰U_{\mathbf{w}} are applied to produce the state |ψ1⟩ketsubscript𝜓1\left|\psi_{1}\right\rangle in step (2). Hence, step (2) can be implemented in time O​(polylog​(M​D)+D+q)𝑂polylog𝑀𝐷𝐷𝑞O(\text{polylog}(MD)+D+q).

In step (3), we first consider the complexity of the unitary operation 𝒜isubscript𝒜𝑖\mathcal{A}_{i}. It contains H𝐻H, U𝐱isubscript𝑈subscript𝐱𝑖U_{\mathbf{x}_{i}}, and U𝐰subscript𝑈𝐰U_{\mathbf{w}} which take time O​(polylog​(M​D)+D+q)𝑂polylog𝑀𝐷𝐷𝑞O(\text{polylog}(MD)+D+q). Then, the quantum amplitude estimation (QPE) block needs O​(1/ϵθ)𝑂1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃O\left({1/\epsilon_{\theta}}\right) applications of Qi=−𝒜i​S00​𝒜i†​S11subscript𝑄𝑖subscript𝒜𝑖subscript𝑆00superscriptsubscript𝒜𝑖†subscript𝑆11Q_{i}=-\mathcal{A}_{i}S_{00}\mathcal{A}_{i}^{\dagger}S_{11} to achieve error ϵθsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃\epsilon_{\theta} brassard2002 . Therefore, the time of accomplishing step (3.1) is O​[(polylog​(M​D)+D+q)/ϵθ]𝑂delimited-[]polylog𝑀𝐷𝐷𝑞subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃O[(\text{polylog}(MD)+D+q)/{\epsilon_{\theta}}]. The runtime O​(log​(1/ϵθ))𝑂log1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃O(\text{log}({1/\epsilon_{\theta}})) zhou2017 of implementing the sine gate can be ignored, which is much smaller than the QPE.

Next, the complexity of steps (3.2)-(3.3) is discussed. The main operation of the two steps includes Un​fsubscript𝑈𝑛𝑓U_{nf}, Oysubscript𝑂𝑦O_{y}, and the quantum arithmetic operation, which are performed to calculate |F​(𝐱⋅𝐰)⟩ket𝐹⋅𝐱𝐰|F({\mathbf{x}}\cdot{\mathbf{w}})\rangle in time O​[(polylog​(D))/ϵm+q]𝑂delimited-[]polylog𝐷subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚𝑞O[{(\text{polylog}(D))/{\epsilon_{m}}}+q]. In step (3.4), the complexity of the controlled rotation is O​(q)𝑂𝑞O(q). Step (3.5) takes time O​[(polylog​(D))/ϵm+(polylog​(M​D)+D+q)/ϵθ]𝑂delimited-[]polylog𝐷subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚polylog𝑀𝐷𝐷𝑞subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃O[{(\text{polylog}(D))/{\epsilon_{m}}}+{(\text{polylog}(MD)+D+q)/{\epsilon_{\theta}}}] to implement the inverse operations of steps (2.2)-(3.3). Putting all the steps together to get the complexity of step (3) as O​[(polylog​(D))/ϵm+(polylog​(M​D)+D+q)/ϵθ]𝑂delimited-[]polylog𝐷subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚polylog𝑀𝐷𝐷𝑞subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃O[{(\text{polylog}(D))/{\epsilon_{m}}}+{(\text{polylog}(MD)+D+q)/{\epsilon_{\theta}}}].

In step (4), the processes of generating the |χj⟩ketsuperscript𝜒𝑗|\chi^{j}\rangle (described in steps (4.1)-(4.3)) are accomplished in time O​(polylog​(M​D)+q)𝑂polylog𝑀𝐷𝑞O(\text{polylog}(MD)+q). According to step (3), a copy of the quantum state |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle is produced in time O​[(polylog​(D))/ϵm+(polylog​(M​D)+D+q)/ϵθ]𝑂delimited-[]polylog𝐷subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚polylog𝑀𝐷𝐷𝑞subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃O[{(\text{polylog}(D))/{\epsilon_{m}}}+{(\text{polylog}(MD)+D+q)/{\epsilon_{\theta}}}]. The swap test is applied O​(P​(1−P)/ϵP2)=O​(1/ϵP2)𝑂𝑃1𝑃superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑃2𝑂1superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑃2O\left({{P\left({1-P}\right)}/\epsilon_{P}^{2}}\right)=O\left({1/\epsilon_{P}^{2}}\right) times to get the result P𝑃P within error ϵPsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑃\epsilon_{P} rebentrost2014 in step (4.4). And each swap test should prepare a copy of |χj⟩ketsuperscript𝜒𝑗|\chi^{j}\rangle and |ψ⟩ket𝜓|\psi\rangle. Therefore, the runtime is {[(polylog​(D))/ϵm+(polylog​(M​D)+D+q)/ϵθ]​ϵP−2}delimited-[]polylog𝐷subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚polylog𝑀𝐷𝐷𝑞subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑃2\left\{[{(\text{polylog}(D))/{\epsilon_{m}}}+{(\text{polylog}(MD)+D+q)/{\epsilon_{\theta}}}]\epsilon_{P}^{-2}\right\} in step (4), that is the complexity of obtaining the desired result.

For convenience, we assume that 𝐰jsuperscript𝐰𝑗\mathbf{w}^{j}, 𝐱ij=O​(1)superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑗𝑂1\mathbf{x}_{i}^{j}=O(1), then ‖𝐰‖norm𝐰\|\mathbf{w}\|, maxi⁡‖𝐱i‖=O​(D)subscript𝑖normsubscript𝐱𝑖𝑂𝐷{\max\limits_{i}\left\|\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\|}=O(\sqrt{D}). Therefore, q=polylog​(D)𝑞polylog𝐷q={\text{polylog}(D)} could fulfill the number of qubit required to store data information. In addition, taking ϵmsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑚\epsilon_{m}, ϵθsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃\epsilon_{\theta}, and ϵPsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑃\epsilon_{P} equaling to ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. After that, the complexity of the entire quantum algorithm to get 𝒈j​(𝐰)superscript𝒈𝑗𝐰\bm{g}^{j}\left(\mathbf{w}\right) (j=0,1,⋯,D−1)𝑗01⋯𝐷1(j=0,1,\cdots,D-1) in each iteration can further simplify into

O​{D​[(polylog​(M​D)+D)/ϵ3]}.𝑂𝐷delimited-[]polylog𝑀𝐷𝐷superscriptitalic-ϵ3O\left\{{D\left[{\left(\text{polylog}\left({MD}\right)+D\right)/\epsilon^{3}}\right]}\right\}. (46)

This means that the time complexity of training gradient is O​(D2​polylog​(M​D))𝑂superscript𝐷2polylog𝑀𝐷O(D^{2}\text{polylog}(MD)) when ϵ−1=polylog​(M​D)superscriptitalic-ϵ1polylog𝑀𝐷\epsilon^{-1}=\text{polylog}(MD), achieving exponential acceleration on the number of data samples. Furthermore, the elements of 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} can also be accessed in time O​(polylog​(D))𝑂polylog𝐷O(\text{polylog}(D)) if they are timely writing in QRAM. In this case, the proposed algorithm has exponential acceleration on the number M𝑀M and the quadratic speedup in the dimensionality D𝐷D, compared with the classical algorithm whose runtime is O​(M​D2)𝑂𝑀superscript𝐷2O(MD^{2}).

IV.2 Security analysis of the QSMC protocol

In this section, the security of the QSMC protocol will be analyzed. For the secure multi-party computing, the attacks from outside and all participants are the challenges, which have to deal with. In the following, we will show these attacks are invalid to our protocol.

Firstly, the outside attacks are discussed. In this protocol, the decoy photons is used to prevent the eavesdropping. This idea is derived from the BB84 protocol bennett1984 , which has been proved unconditionally safe. Here, we take the intercept-resend attack as an example to demonstrate. If an outside eavesdropper Eve attempts to intercept the particles sent from Alice and replaces them with his own fake particles, he will introduce extra error rate 1−(di+12​di)δ1superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖12subscript𝑑𝑖𝛿1-\left(\frac{d_{i}+1}{2d_{i}}\right)^{\delta}. Therefore, Eve will be detected in Step M3 through security analysis.

Secondly, the participant attacks are analyzed. In the proposed protocol, the participants include the server (Alice) and clients (BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k}, k=1,2,⋯,K𝑘12⋯𝐾k=1,2,\cdots,K) who can access more information. Therefore, the participant attacks from dishonest clients or server should be considered.

For the participant attack from dishonest clients, there are only considering the extreme case that K−1𝐾1K-1 clients Bob1,⋯,Bobk−1,Bobk+1,⋯,BobKsubscriptBob1⋯subscriptBob𝑘1subscriptBob𝑘1⋯subscriptBob𝐾{\rm Bob}_{1},\cdots,{\rm Bob}_{k-1},{\rm Bob}_{k+1},\cdots,{\rm Bob}_{K} collude together to steal the secret from BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k}, because K−1𝐾1K-1 clients have the most powerful strength. In this case, even if the dishonest clients share their information, they cannot deduce oksubscript𝑜𝑘o_{k} without the help of Alice. That means they can’t obtain the secret sk,ijsuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖𝑗s_{k,i}^{j} by sk,i′⁣j=sk,ij+oksuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖′𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖𝑗subscript𝑜𝑘s_{k,i}^{\prime j}=s_{k,i}^{j}+o_{k}. Thus, our algorithm can resist the collusion attack of dishonest BobksubscriptBob𝑘{\rm Bob}_{k}.

For the attack from Alice, the semi-honest Alice may steal the private information of Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} without conspiring with any one. In Step M4, Alice collects sk,i′⁣jsuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖′𝑗s_{k,i}^{\prime j} for k=1,2,⋯,K𝑘12⋯𝐾k=1,2,\cdots,K. However, she still cannot learn sk,ijsuperscriptsubscript𝑠𝑘𝑖𝑗s_{k,i}^{j} due to the lack of knowledge about oksubscript𝑜𝑘o_{k} which from clients.

V Application: Training the Federated Linear Regression Model

V.1 Quantum federated linear regression algorithm

Linear regression (LR) is an important supervised learning algorithm, which establishes a model of the relationship between the variable 𝐱isubscript𝐱𝑖\mathbf{x}_{i} and the observation yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}. It was wide application in the scientific fields of biology, finance, and so on geron2022 . LR models are also usually fitted by minimizing the function in Eq. (1) and choosing f​(𝐱i⋅𝐰)=𝐱i⋅𝐰+b𝑓⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰𝑏{f\left({\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}}\right)}={\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}}+{b} (b𝑏b is a migration parameter).

In this section, we research a quantum federated linear regression (QFLR) algorithm based on gradient descent. The main idea is to implement the function

F​(𝐱i⋅𝐰)=𝐱i⋅𝐰+b−yi.𝐹⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰𝑏subscript𝑦𝑖F\left({\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}}\right)=\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}+b-y_{i}. (47)

So that QFLGD algorithm can be applied by a simple modification. The state |𝐱i⋅𝐰⟩ket⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰|{\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}}\rangle about 𝐱i⋅𝐰⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰{\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}} can be generated according to algorithm 1. Then, the state |𝐱i⋅𝐰+b−yi⟩ket⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰𝑏subscript𝑦𝑖|\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}+b-y_{i}\rangle is produced in the following steps.

V.2 Numerical Simulation

In this section, the numerical simulation of the QFLR algorithm will be presented. In our simulation, two clients (Bob1subscriptBob1{\rm Bob}_{1}, Bob2subscriptBob2{\rm Bob}_{2}) trained the QFLR model with a sever (Alice). The experiment is implemented on the Qiskit quantum computing framework aleksandrowicz2019qiskit . The initial weight 𝐰​(0)=(0.866,0.5)𝐰00.8660.5\mathbf{w}(0)=(0.866,0.5) and the migration parameter b=0𝑏0b=0 are selected by Alice. Bob1subscriptBob1{\rm Bob}_{1} chooses an input vector 𝐱=(2,3.464)𝐱23.464\mathbf{x}=(2,3.464) which corresponds the observation y=2.464𝑦2.464y=2.464. In the process of training the federated linear regression model, the main is to achieve the perfect F​(𝐱i⋅𝐰)𝐹⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰F\left({\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}}\right) calculation. That is, quantum computing F​(𝐱i⋅𝐰)𝐹⋅subscript𝐱𝑖𝐰F\left({\mathbf{x}_{i}\cdot\mathbf{w}}\right) values are required to be able to be stored in quantum registers with small error. An experiment of this step is presented with Bob1subscriptBob1{\rm Bob}_{1}’s data. With loss of generality, setting c1=4subscript𝑐14c_{1}=4, c2=1subscript𝑐21c_{2}=1, and the error ϵθ=0.0001subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜃0.0001\epsilon_{\theta}=0.0001 of quantum phase estimation. F​(𝐱⋅𝐰)=4−16​sin2⁡(θ~​π/24)+0−2.464=1,𝐹⋅𝐱𝐰416superscript2~𝜃𝜋superscript2402.4641\begin{split}F\left({\mathbf{x}\cdot\mathbf{w}}\right)=4-16{\sin}^{2}\left({\widetilde{\theta}\pi/2^{4}}\right)+0-2.464=1,\end{split} (52)

could be obtained.

Its circuit is designed as exhibited in Fig. 6 and encoded via Qiskit. (52)), the experimental result has an error of 0.0770.0770.077 which is tolerable. Subsequently, Bob1subscriptBob1{\rm Bob}_{1} can estimate 𝒈11≈1.846superscriptsubscript𝒈111.846\bm{g}_{1}^{1}\approx 1.846 and 𝒈12≈3.197superscriptsubscript𝒈123.197\bm{g}_{1}^{2}\approx 3.197 by performing swap test. At same time, Bob2subscriptBob2{\rm Bob}_{2} estimates F​(𝐱′⋅𝐰)≈2.115𝐹⋅superscript𝐱′𝐰2.115F\left({\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\cdot\mathbf{w}}\right)\approx 2.115, 𝒈21≈3.197superscriptsubscript𝒈213.197\bm{g}_{2}^{1}\approx 3.197, and 𝒈22≈9.157superscriptsubscript𝒈229.157\bm{g}_{2}^{2}\approx 9.157 of his data via similar experiment.

As the analogous process of the example shown in III.3, Alice calculates the federated gradient G=(3.57,6.18)𝐺3.576.18G=(3.57,6.18) via the QSMC protocol. Theoretical analysis shows that the error is within 12%percent1212\% of the actual solution (3.5,6.06)3.56.06(3.5,6.06) which is obtained in the example. Thus, the training algorithm is found to be successful.

VI Conclusions

We have presented a framework for federated learning based on gradient descent that can securely implement FL over an exponentially large data set. In this framework, we first proposed a quantum gradient descent algorithm that allowed the time-consuming gradient calculation to be done on a quantum computer. And the time complexity analysis is shown that our algorithm is exponentially faster than its classical counterpart on the number of data samples when the error 1/ϵ=polylog​(M​D)1italic-ϵpolylog𝑀𝐷1/\epsilon=\text{polylog}(MD). Furthermore, the QGD algorithm could also achieve quadratic speedup on the dimensionality of the data sample if the parameters 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} are stored in QRAM timely. Secondly, we gave a quantum secure multi-party computation protocol to calculate the federated gradient securely. The evidence is demonstrated that the proposed protocol could resist some common outside and participant attacks, such as the intercept-resend attack. Finally, we indicated how to apply it to train a federated linear regression model and simulated some steps with the help of the Qiskit quantum computing framework. The results also showed the effectiveness of QFLGD. In summary, the presented framework demonstrates the intriguing potential of achieving large-scale private distributed learning with quantum technologies and provides a valuable guide for exploring quantum advantages in real-life machine learning applications from the security perspective.

We hope that our proposed framework can further realize on a quantum platform with the gradual maturity of quantum technology. For example, how to implement the whole QFLGD process on the noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices is worth further exploration, and we will make more efforts.

Appendix B An example of extracting the parameter 𝐰​(n)𝐰𝑛\mathbf{w}(n) information

In Sec. III.2, a way to prepare a quantum state of 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} without the help of QRAM is shown in step (1.2). To further demonstrate it, an example is given in this appendix.

For convenience, supposing that 𝐰​(n)=𝐰∈ℝ4𝐰𝑛𝐰superscriptℝ4\mathbf{w}(n)=\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{4}. Then,we can get angle parameters ϑ10subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϑ01\vartheta^{0}_{1}, ϑ20subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϑ02\vartheta^{0}_{2}, and ϑ21subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϑ12\vartheta^{1}_{2} which are satisfied

cos⁡(ϑ10)=h10h00,sin⁡(ϑ10)=h11h00,cos⁡(ϑ20)=h20h10,sin⁡(ϑ20)=h21h10,cos⁡(ϑ21)=h22h11,sin⁡(ϑ21)=h23h11,\begin{split}&{\cos(\vartheta^{0}_{1})=\frac{h^{0}_{1}}{h^{0}_{0}}},~{}~{}~{}~{}{\sin(\vartheta^{0}_{1})=\frac{h^{1}_{1}}{h^{0}_{0}}},\\ &{\cos(\vartheta^{0}_{2})=\frac{h^{0}_{2}}{h^{0}_{1}}},~{}~{}~{}~{}{\sin(\vartheta^{0}_{2})=\frac{h^{1}_{2}}{h^{0}_{1}}},\\ &{\cos(\vartheta^{1}_{2})=\frac{h^{2}_{2}}{h^{1}_{1}}},~{}~{}~{}~{}{\sin(\vartheta^{1}_{2})=\frac{h^{3}_{2}}{h^{1}_{1}}},\end{split} (63)

according to Eq. (15). The value of htjsubscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑗𝑡h^{j}_{t} (t=0,1,2𝑡012t=0,1,2) are shown in Fig. 8, such as h2j=𝐰jsubscriptsuperscriptℎ𝑗2superscript𝐰𝑗h^{j}_{2}=\mathbf{w}^{j} for j=0,1,2,3𝑗0123j=0,1,2,3.

Then, the operations are defined as

U​(ϑ1)=R​(ϑ10)⊗I,U​(ϑ2)=|0⟩​⟨0|⊗R​(ϑ20)+|1⟩​⟨1|⊗R​(ϑ21),formulae-sequence𝑈subscriptbold-italic-ϑ1tensor-product𝑅subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϑ01𝐼𝑈subscriptbold-italic-ϑ2tensor-productket0bra0𝑅subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϑ02tensor-productket1bra1𝑅subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϑ12\begin{split}&U(\bm{\vartheta}_{1})=R({\vartheta}^{0}_{1})\otimes I,\\ &U(\bm{\vartheta}_{2})=|0\rangle\langle 0|\otimes R({\vartheta}^{0}_{2})+|1\rangle\langle 1|\otimes R({\vartheta}^{1}_{2}),\end{split} (64)

based on R​(ϑ)=[cos⁡(ϑ)−sin⁡(ϑ)sin⁡(ϑ)cos⁡(ϑ)]𝑅italic-ϑmatrixitalic-ϑitalic-ϑitalic-ϑitalic-ϑR(\vartheta)=\begin{bmatrix}\cos{(\vartheta)}&-\sin{(\vartheta)}\\ \sin{(\vartheta)}&\cos{(\vartheta)}\\ \end{bmatrix}. It is easy to verify that

U​(ϑ2)​U​(ϑ1)​|00⟩=1‖𝐰‖​(𝐰0​|00⟩+𝐰1​|01⟩+𝐰2​|10⟩+𝐰3​|11⟩).𝑈subscriptbold-italic-ϑ2𝑈subscriptbold-italic-ϑ1ket001norm𝐰superscript𝐰0ket00superscript𝐰1ket01superscript𝐰2ket10superscript𝐰3ket11\begin{split}&U(\bm{\vartheta}_{2})U(\bm{\vartheta}_{1})|00\rangle\\ =&\frac{1}{\left\|\mathbf{w}\right\|}(\mathbf{w}^{0}|00\rangle+\mathbf{w}^{1}|01\rangle+\mathbf{w}^{2}|10\rangle+\mathbf{w}^{3}|11\rangle).\end{split} (65)

Thus, the quantum state of 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} can be obtained.
